title: The Slow AI Curriculum for AI Literacy
subtitle: A 12-month programme in critical inquiry to better understand how to engage with AI effectively and ethically.
author: Dr Sam Illingworth
content_html:
Over the past six months, Slow AI has evolved into a significant community of practice. Conversations with many of you confirm that Slow AI readers require a structured framework to navigate the ethical and pedagogical complexities of AI.

To meet this need, I’m introducing a paid tier to support the launch of The Slow AI Curriculum for AI Literacy, a twelve-month pedagogical programme designed to foster critical discernment in an era of synthetic acceleration.

The first one hundred scholars to join will receive an inaugural rate of £50 for the year.

Join the Slow AI Curriculum

The Pedagogical Vision

Most AI instruction prioritises technical optimisation and extraction. This curriculum offers an alternative.

The curriculum is underpinned by my work as a Full Professor of Creative Pedagogies and the research in my forthcoming book, GenAI in Higher Education (Bloomsbury Academic). Launching as an open-access title on the 22nd of January, this work establishes the critical framework we will use to navigate the tensions between human agency and synthetic systems.

We will use the humanities to interrogate technology, moving beyond ‘how to use’ toward an understanding of ‘how to think.’

We will prioritise human judgement over algorithmic speed and questions over conclusions.

The 2026 Syllabus

The syllabus follows a thematic arc of critical inquiry. Each month addresses a specific tension between human agency and synthetic systems.

  • January. The Myth of Neutrality (Data Origins and Bias)

  • February. Synthetic Empathy (Affective Computing and Care)

  • March. Security and Surveillance (Privacy and Institutional Control)

  • April. The Labour of AI (Ghost Work and Extraction)

  • May. Creative Agency (Mimicry versus Imagination)

  • June. Ecological Costs (Environmental Impacts)

  • July. Memory and Forgetting (Data Retention and Identity)

  • August. Epistemic Crisis (Deepfakes and the Collapse of Truth)

  • September. AI and Student Belonging (Pedagogy versus Policing)

  • October. Digital Colonialism (Algorithmic Hegemony and Cultural Erasure)

  • November. Algorithmic Governance (Automated Law and Ethics)

  • December. The Slow AI Manifesto (Developing a Personal Ethical Framework)

Format and Delivery

We meet on the last Thursday of every month at 14:00 UK time via Zoom. Each 45-minute seminar follows this structure:

  1. Theory (15 Minutes). I introduce a theoretical concept grounded in a peer-reviewed, open-access academic paper. I provide the synthesis so that no prior reading is required.

  2. The Critical Prompt (10 Minutes). We apply the theory to a singular, provocative prompt to observe the AI output.

  3. Dialogue (20 Minutes). A moderated discussion in the chat to synthesise our findings and share observations.

Paid members receive a follow up post containing the session recording. This post also includes the linked academic paper and a summary of critical literacy takeaways.

The Certificate of Critical AI Literacy

The Certificate of Critical AI Literacy provides formal recognition of this work. It serves as evidence of engagement for those seeking professional development credit, and will be awarded to all those who complete the syllabus.

I recognise that for many, this curriculum represents a professional requirement to keep pace with shifting landscapes. To assist with institutional reimbursement, I have provided a template below. You may use this to request that your employer covers the cost of the curriculum as part of your formal continuing professional development (CPD).

Download the template

A Taster of the curriculum

To understand the academic rigor and depth of this programme, I have prepared a detailed handbook. This document outlines the theoretical grounding, monthly syllabus, and the structure of our moderated dialogue.

2026 Handbook for Critical AI Literacy

I encourage you to read this handbook before deciding to upgrade. It provides a clear roadmap of how we will navigate issues such as synthetic empathy, algorithmic governance, and digital colonialism over the coming year.

The Choice of Practice

The current trajectory of AI development is predicated on the assumption that we will all move faster, think less, and accept synthetic outputs as a default state. This curriculum is an invitation to resist that momentum.

If you value the depth of this research and the necessity of this critique, I invite you to join as an Inaugural Scholar.

  • Inaugural Scholar Offer (£50). Limited to the first one hundred annual subscribers. (33% discount). SOLD OUT

  • Founding Member (£300). Includes a private sixty minute advisory consultation. Capped at twenty memberships.

  • Standard Annual Membership (£75). Full access to the 2026 syllabus and certification.

Join the Slow AI Curriculum

All other Slow AI written posts will remain free and open access.

The access link and password for the first inquiry, 'The Myth of Neutrality' (29th January at 14:00 UK time), will be provided for all paid members via email. To ensure an engaged community of practice, I’m limiting this live webinar to 300 participants. Paid subscribers receive priority access to these places. If any seats remain 48 hours before the session, I will circulate a registration link to the wider Slow AI community.

Go Slow.

Sam
